conclusion: Consider principles of shadow formation and effect of light source position
Image shows four objects: cigarette box, pencil, egg, and clock
Shadows A, B, C, and D are cast on the ground due to light source to the left
Light source moving to the right changes angle of incidence, affecting shadows' position and size
Shadows form on opposite side of light source relative to object
Light source directly above causes shadows to move closer to base of objects
Size of shadow determined by angle and distance of light source
Light source directly above makes shadows smaller due to perpendicular light rays
Cigarette box shadow shrinks and aligns more closely with base when light is directly above
Pencil shadow becomes shorter and more concentrated beneath pencil with overhead light
Egg shadow becomes smaller and more circular directly beneath egg with overhead light
Clock shadow becomes more compact and directly beneath clock with overhead light
Shadows A, B, C, and D move closer to base and become smaller with overhead light source
